awd_titl_txt: US-French Collaboration: Mechanisms of emergent OscillaTIONs in the septo-hippocampal network-MOTION
awd_abstract_narration:
The hippocampus in mammals is a brain area important for learning and memory that is also implicated in several major neurological and psychiatric disorders including epilepsy, autism, schizophrenia and Alzheimer's disease. Prior research revealed that learning and memory-related information processing in the hippocampus critically depends on clock-like, rhythmic electrical signals elicited by an adjacent brain structure called the septum. However, how the oscillatory neuronal activity emerges from the closely interconnected neuronal networks of the septum and the hippocampus is not understood. The current project will employ novel, uniquely high-throughput experimental approaches in mice integrated with innovative, biologically realistic, large-scale supercomputer-based theoretical modeling techniques to identify key mechanisms underlying rhythmic electrical signal generation in septo-hippocampal circuits. The project represents a potentially major milestone in the development of biologically based realistic computer models of the brain, as it would allow the generation and testing of hypotheses concerning network mechanisms of behaviorally relevant oscillatory neuronal activity with unparalleled biological realism, precision and speed. In addition, the experimental knowledge base and the large-scale computational brain models will be placed in open-source databases (including ModelDB for network models at http://senselab.med.yale.edu/modeldb/, and Neuromorpho for biological structural data at http://neuromorpho.org/) that are freely accessible for the unrestricted use by the scientific community. This project involves extensive postdoctoral training in neuroinformatics.  

This award is co-funded by NSF's Office of the Director, International Science and Engineering, and a companion project is being funded by the French National Research Agency (ANR).

por.por_cntn:
Virtually all neuronal networks in the brain generate rhythmic electrical activities, which are oscillatory signals generated by large numbers of neurons communicating with each other in a temporally precisely controlled fashion. Such brain rhythms can be slow (<10 cycles per second) or fast (>100 cycles per second), and they are important for distinct behaviorally and cognitively relevant processes such as learning and memory and spatial navigation. However, precisely how neuronal networks generate brain rhythms of widely different frequences and functions are not well understood.

We focused on a key brain area, the CA1 region of the hippocampus, that is known to support diverse cognitive tasks requiring coordination of neuronal activities provided by physiological network oscillations including the theta rhythm (5 to 10 cycles per second) that is important for spatial navigation and other information processing tasks related to learning and memory. We took advantage of recent advances in supercomputing power and the increasing availability of high-resolution neurobiological data about the hippocampal circuits to design, develop and construct biologically relevant, full-scale, 1:1 computational models of the hippocampus where every neuron and neuron-to-neuron connection (called a synapse) is explicitly represented.

Simulations of activity generated by these novel, biologically strongly constrained, highly realistic neuronal network models, consisting of hundreds of thousands of individual virtual brain cells and over 5 billion synapses, were run on supercomputers to study the mechanisms that underlie the generation of theta oscillations. The research revealed that theta rhythm can spontaneously emerge from the CA1 circuit, and it also identified fundamentally new cellular-synaptic mechanisms of theta generation in the hippocampus including key roles for specific inhibitory neuron types. These novel mechanistic insights will inspire new areas of experimental and computational modeling investigations aimed at deepening our understanding of the emergence of distinct rhythmic brain activities in various neuronal circuits associated with different information processing tasks.

In addition, we also developed a new, versatile simulation platform called SimTracker that enables the management, organization, construction, running and sharing of large, biologically precise network models on supercomputers and the rational derivation of simplified models from the complex model. Importantly, SimTracker is not only a user-friendly but also an entirely open-source toolbox that will be useful for neuronal network modellers of different skills to address a wide variety of neurobiological problems. All of our models and computer algorithms are freely available and shared on the web in open data bases such as Open Source Brain and ModelDB for free use by the scientific community across the world.

Taken together, these results represent an exciting milestone in strictly data-driven neurbiological network modeling that will be built upon in the future by both theoretical and experimental research programs.
